metadata.name: Orthography, Diacritics & Writing Systems
metadata.description: Terms related to writing systems, diacritics, and orthographic conventions, including Ancient and Modern Greek.

entries.definition: The set of conventions for writing a language, including spelling, capitalization, and punctuation.
examples: Modern Greek orthography uses only the tonos accent, unlike Ancient Greek which used multiple diacritics.

entries.definition: A mark added to a letter to indicate a modification in pronunciation, stress, or tone.
A sequence of two letters representing a single phoneme or a single orthographic unit (grapheme), e.g. 'sh' in English representing /ʃ/.
entries.notes: Digraphs contrast with single-letter graphemes and with consonant clusters where each letter maps to a separate phoneme.

entries.definition: A diacritic (´) used in Modern Greek to indicate the stressed syllable of a word.
A diacritic (´) used in Ancient Greek to indicate a rising pitch on a syllable.
A diacritic (`) in Ancient Greek that indicates a lowering of pitch, often replacing an acute at the end of a word.
A diacritic (ˆ) in Ancient Greek showing a rising then falling pitch on a long vowel or diphthong.
A diacritic in Ancient Greek placed over initial vowels or rho: rough (῾) for an 'h' sound, smooth (᾿) for no sound.
